definitions: make something ineffective by opposing or canceling its effect or force
deny the existence or truth of something by contradicting or disproving it
express the opposite or absence of something in logic or grammar
examples: The new evidence completely negates his earlier testimony in court
These safety measures negate the risk of serious workplace injuries
The scientist tried to negate the theory with experimental data
His actions negate everything he claimed to believe in
In French, you negate verbs by adding ne and pas
The philosopher negated the premise to test the argument's validity

definitions: formally reject or refuse to accept a proposal or request
exercise veto power to prevent something from being approved
examples: The committee negatived the proposal after lengthy deliberation yesterday
Parliament negatived the bill by a narrow margin of votes
The president negatived the legislation despite strong congressional support
The board negatived his request for additional research funding

definitions: fail to care for someone or something properly through lack of attention
fail or forget to do something that should be done regularly
deliberately pay no attention to something important or ignore it
examples: She neglected her garden during the long business trip
Parents who neglect their children face serious legal consequences
He neglected to mention the deadline had already passed
Many students neglect their health during final exam week
The company neglected safety warnings from multiple regulatory agencies
Politicians often neglect the concerns of their poorest constituents

definitions: discuss something with others to reach an agreement through compromise and bargaining
successfully navigate or travel through a difficult path or obstacle course
examples: The union will negotiate better wages with management next month
Diplomats negotiated a ceasefire between the warring nations yesterday
The driver carefully negotiated the sharp mountain curves at dawn
She negotiated the crowded marketplace with her heavy shopping bags

definitions: be located next to or very near something in physical space
share a common border or boundary with another place or thing
examples: Our property neighbors the national forest on three sides
The new coffee shop neighbors several popular restaurants downtown
Canada neighbors the United States along their extensive shared border
The two buildings neighbor each other across a narrow alley

definitions: be located next to or very near something in physical space
share a common border or boundary with another place or thing
examples: The ancient church neighbours the village green and market square
Their garden neighbours ours along the eastern hedge boundary
France neighbours several countries including Spain and Germany
The two estates neighbour each other across the river valley

definitions: give oneself courage or confidence to face a difficult or frightening situation
mentally prepare and strengthen oneself for an unpleasant or challenging task
examples: She nerved herself to speak publicly about her personal struggles
The soldiers nerved themselves before entering the dangerous combat zone
He nerved himself for the difficult conversation with his boss
The performer nerved herself before stepping onto the enormous stage

definitions: build or occupy a nest for laying eggs and raising young
fit objects inside one another in a compact hierarchical arrangement
settle oneself comfortably and snugly in a cozy protected place
examples: Eagles nest high in the mountain cliffs every spring
The robins nested in our apple tree for three consecutive years
These measuring cups nest perfectly inside each other for storage
The programmer nested several loops within the main function code
The cat nested in the warm laundry basket all afternoon
Children love to nest in blanket forts during cold winter days

definitions: settle oneself comfortably against or close to someone or something warm
position something carefully in a protected or comfortable place
lie in a sheltered position surrounded by or against something protective
examples: The baby nestled against her mother's warm shoulder peacefully
She nestled deeper into the soft armchair with her book
He nestled the fragile eggs in layers of soft tissue paper
The jeweler nestled each gem in its velvet-lined compartment carefully
The cottage nestles among tall pine trees near the lake
Small villages nestle in the valleys between towering mountain peaks

definitions: catch or trap something using a net or similar meshed device
earn or produce as profit after all expenses and taxes are deducted
succeed in obtaining or achieving something as a final result
examples: The fishermen netted hundreds of salmon during spawning season
Scientists netted butterflies for their migration research study yesterday
The company netted five million dollars after paying all expenses
She nets about three thousand monthly after taxes and deductions
His research netted him a prestigious award from the academy
The investigation netted several arrests of high-ranking officials yesterday

definitions: earn or produce as profit after all expenses and taxes are deducted
examples: The business netted substantial profits during the holiday shopping season
She netted twice her usual commission after the major sale

definitions: irritate or annoy someone deliberately to provoke a reaction
make someone feel annoyed or slightly angry through persistent behavior
examples: His constant criticism nettled her throughout the entire meeting yesterday
The reporter's questions clearly nettled the politician during the interview
It nettles him when people arrive late without calling first
Her dismissive attitude nettled everyone at the community gathering yesterday

definitions: connect multiple computers or systems together to share resources and information
build professional or social connections with people for mutual benefit
broadcast a program simultaneously across multiple stations or channels
examples: The IT department networked all office computers over the weekend
They networked the printers to allow access from any workstation
She networked actively at the conference to find potential clients
Successful entrepreneurs network constantly to expand their business opportunities
The company will network the show across fifty affiliate stations
They networked the presidential address to reach maximum viewership nationwide

definitions: surgically remove the reproductive organs of an animal to prevent breeding
remove the power or effectiveness of something making it harmless or ineffective
examples: The veterinarian will neuter your cat during tomorrow's scheduled appointment
Animal shelters neuter pets before putting them up for adoption
The amendment effectively neutered the bill's most important provisions yesterday
Critics argued the regulations would neuter the agency's enforcement capabilities

definitions: make something ineffective by counteracting or canceling its force or effect
counteract or offset an undesirable effect with an opposing force
make a substance chemically neutral by combining acid with base
examples: Special forces neutralised the terrorist threat before dawn this morning
The new policy neutralises any advantage competitors might have gained
This medication neutralises stomach acid to relieve heartburn symptoms quickly
The air freshener neutralises unpleasant odors rather than masking them
You must neutralise the acid solution before disposing of it safely
The chemist neutralised the spill using sodium bicarbonate solution yesterday

definitions: make something ineffective by counteracting or canceling its force or effect
counteract or offset an undesirable effect with an opposing force
make a substance chemically neutral by combining acid with base
examples: Security forces neutralized the bomb threat at the airport yesterday
The company neutralized their competitor's marketing advantage through innovation
Antacids neutralize excess stomach acid to provide quick relief
Trees neutralize carbon dioxide through the process of photosynthesis
Always neutralize acidic waste before pouring it down the drain
The lab technician neutralized the corrosive solution with careful precision

definitions: make a small cut or notch in something's surface accidentally or deliberately
steal something quickly and opportunistically often in informal British usage
arrest or catch someone for a crime in British police slang
examples: He nicked his chin while shaving hurriedly this morning
The carpenter nicked the wood slightly with his chisel yesterday
Someone nicked my bicycle from outside the grocery store yesterday
Kids often nicked sweets from the corner shop years ago
The police nicked him for drunk driving last Friday night
They finally nicked the burglar after months of investigation

definitions: coat or plate something with a thin layer of nickel metal for protection
examples: The manufacturer nickels all metal parts to prevent rust formation
They nickeled the vintage car bumpers during the restoration process

definitions: give someone or something an informal name different from their real name
examples: His friends nicknamed him Ace because of his tennis skills
The locals nicknamed the old bridge Shaky Pete years ago

definitions: pinch or squeeze something sharply between two surfaces or points
give a quick sharp bite with the teeth especially playfully
move somewhere quickly for a brief visit or errand
stop something's growth or development at an early stage
examples: The cold wind nipped at our faces during the winter hike
She nipped his arm playfully to get his attention yesterday
The puppy nipped at my heels while we played outside
The small terrier nipped the mailman's ankle this morning
I'll just nip to the store for some milk quickly
She nipped out during lunch to run a quick errand
The late frost nipped the new buds on the fruit trees
We need to nip this problem in the bud immediately

definitions: reject or refuse something decisively and completely in informal usage
cancel or put an end to plans or proposals abruptly
examples: The board nixed the expensive marketing proposal without further discussion
She immediately nixed his suggestion to skip the safety briefing
They nixed the outdoor concert due to threatening weather conditions
Management nixed our plans for a company retreat this year

definitions: move one's head up and down as a gesture or involuntary motion
indicate agreement or understanding by moving the head up and down
let one's head fall forward when drowsy or fall briefly asleep
examples: She nodded slowly while listening to the detailed instructions
The teacher nodded to acknowledge each student entering the classroom
Everyone nodded when asked if they understood the new policy
He nodded his approval of the architectural design plans yesterday
The elderly man nodded off during the long afternoon sermon
Students often nod off during boring lectures after lunch

definitions: spread rumors or information about something informally through gossip
make something publicly known especially through unofficial channels
examples: Someone noised the merger plans around the office before announcement
The scandal was noised throughout the small town within hours
It was noised abroad that the company faced bankruptcy soon
News of their engagement was noised about the entire neighborhood

definitions: formally propose someone as a candidate for an office or honor
officially appoint someone to a position or role with formal authority
examples: The committee nominated her for president of the organization yesterday
Several members nominated him for the lifetime achievement award
The president nominated a new justice to the Supreme Court
The board nominated three executives to oversee the merger process

definitions: tie or form a rope into a noose with a sliding knot
catch or trap something using a noose or similar snaring device
examples: The sailor noosed the rope to secure the equipment properly
He carefully noosed the cord to create an adjustable loop
Wildlife officers noosed the escaped alligator near the residential area
Rangers noosed the injured deer to provide medical treatment safely

definitions: make something conform to a normal or standard state or condition
establish or resume normal diplomatic or political relations between countries
adjust data to a common scale or standard format in technical contexts
examples: The therapy helped normalize his sleep patterns within several weeks
Exercise can normalize blood pressure in many patients naturally
The two countries normalized relations after decades of hostility
Cuba and the US normalized diplomatic ties in recent years
The software normalizes all database entries to prevent redundancy errors
Researchers normalized the test scores before conducting statistical analysis

definitions: push or nuzzle something with the nose like animals often do
move forward slowly and carefully especially through obstacles or traffic
investigate or pry into matters that don't concern you inappropriately
examples: The dog nosed the ball across the yard playfully yesterday
The horse nosed her hand looking for treats this morning
The car nosed through heavy traffic during rush hour yesterday
The ship nosed carefully into the crowded harbor at dawn
Stop nosing into my personal affairs all the time please
Reporters were nosing around the courthouse looking for information

definitions: cut a V-shaped indentation in something's edge or surface
achieve or record something as adding to a series of accomplishments
examples: The carpenter notched the beam to fit perfectly with another
Native Americans notched arrows for better flight stability centuries ago
The team notched another victory in yesterday's championship game
She notched up her fifth consecutive sales record this quarter

definitions: notice or observe something with careful attention to detail
write down information as a record or reminder for future reference
mention or remark on something specifically to draw attention to it
examples: She noted several errors in the financial report yesterday
Scientists noted unusual behavior in the test subjects this week
Please note the meeting time in your calendar for tomorrow
The secretary noted every important point during the lengthy presentation
The report noted that sales increased significantly last quarter
He noted the importance of early intervention in his speech

definitions: become aware of something through observation or attention
observe or pay attention to something with conscious awareness
give formal notification especially regarding employment or legal matters
examples: I noticed a strange smell coming from the basement yesterday
Did you notice how nervous she seemed during the interview?
The teacher noticed every student's individual learning style carefully
Security guards notice suspicious behavior throughout their shifts constantly
She noticed her employer about resigning with two weeks advance
Tenants must notice landlords thirty days before moving out

definitions: formally or officially inform someone about something important or required
alert relevant parties about an event or situation requiring their attention
examples: The school will notify parents about the schedule change immediately
Banks must notify customers of any suspicious account activity promptly
Please notify the authorities if you witness any criminal activity
The system automatically notifies users when updates are available

definitions: provide food or other substances necessary for growth and health
support or encourage the development and growth of something
cherish and provide emotional sustenance to feelings or relationships
examples: Mother's milk nourishes infants with essential antibodies and nutrients
These vegetables nourish your body with important vitamins and minerals
Good teachers nourish young minds with knowledge and curiosity
Regular practice nourishes musical talent over many years of dedication
She nourished hopes of becoming a professional artist someday
They nourished their friendship through decades of regular correspondence

definitions: push someone or something gently with the elbow or another body part
gently encourage or persuade someone toward a particular action or decision
examples: She nudged him awake when the meeting was about to start
The cat nudged my hand wanting more attention and petting
His parents nudged him toward a career in medicine gently
The coach nudged the team to practice harder before championships

definitions: attack or destroy with nuclear weapons in military contexts
heat food quickly in a microwave oven in informal usage
completely destroy or eliminate something thoroughly and decisively
examples: Military strategists debated whether to nuke enemy installations during wartime
The movie depicted a scenario where cities were nuked accidentally
Just nuke the leftovers for two minutes in the microwave
I nuked some popcorn for our movie night yesterday evening
The virus nuked all the files on my computer yesterday
The company nuked the entire project after discovering major flaws

definitions: make something legally null and void removing all legal force
make something ineffective or worthless by canceling its power or validity
examples: The court nullified the contract due to fraudulent misrepresentation yesterday
The judge nullified the marriage because of improper documentation
Bad weather nullified our carefully planned outdoor wedding reception completely
One mistake can nullify years of hard work and dedication

definitions: make a part of the body unable to feel sensation temporarily
make someone unable to feel emotions due to shock or trauma
examples: The dentist numbed my mouth before filling the cavity yesterday
Cold weather quickly numbs your fingers and toes outdoors
The tragic news numbed everyone who heard about the accident
Years of disappointment had numbed him to further setbacks completely

definitions: assign numbers to things in sequence for identification or organization
count or calculate the total quantity of items in a group
include someone or something as part of a particular group
examples: Please number the pages before submitting your final manuscript tomorrow
The librarian numbered each book for the inventory system carefully
The crowd numbered several thousand at the political rally yesterday
Scientists number the endangered species at less than one hundred
She numbers among the greatest writers of her generation today
I number him among my closest and most trusted friends

definitions: take care of sick or injured people providing medical attention
feed a baby with milk from the breast or bottle
hold onto and cultivate a feeling or grievance over time
consume a drink slowly over an extended period savoring it
examples: She nursed her mother through a long illness last year
The veterinarian nursed the injured bird back to health carefully
She nurses her baby every three hours throughout the day
Many mothers nurse their infants for the first year exclusively
He nursed a grudge against his former partner for years
She nursed dreams of becoming a famous actress since childhood
He nursed his whiskey while watching the sunset slowly fade
She nursed her coffee throughout the long morning meeting yesterday

definitions: care for and protect someone or something while they are growing
help or encourage the development of abilities or qualities over time
cultivate and develop ideas or plans with careful persistent attention
examples: Parents nurture their children with love and guidance throughout childhood
The gardener nurtured the seedlings until they grew strong enough
Good schools nurture creativity and critical thinking in young students
Mentors nurture talent in their protégés over many years patiently
Scientists nurture hypotheses through years of careful research and testing
She nurtured the business idea before launching her startup company

definitions: gather or harvest nuts from trees during the appropriate season
strike someone with one's head in informal British usage
examples: Squirrels nut frantically in autumn preparing for winter months ahead
The children went nutting in the forest yesterday afternoon together
The angry player nutted his opponent during the heated match
He nutted the attacker in self-defense breaking his nose instantly

definitions: follow commands or instructions given by someone in authority
act in accordance with rules or laws without resistance
examples: Children should obey their parents and teachers at all times
Soldiers must obey orders from their commanding officers immediately
Citizens are expected to obey traffic laws for everyone's safety
All employees must obey company policies regarding workplace conduct

definitions: express disagreement or disapproval about something verbally or in writing
formally oppose or protest against something in legal or official contexts
examples: She objected to the noise from the construction site nearby
Several members objected when the proposal was first presented yesterday
The defense attorney objected to the prosecutor's line of questioning
Neighbors formally objected to the building permit application last month

definitions: legally or contractually bind someone to do something specific
morally or ethically compel someone to take a particular action
examples: The contract obligates both parties to complete the work timely
The agreement obligates us to pay monthly installments regularly
His promise obligated him to help despite the inconvenience involved
Professional ethics obligate doctors to maintain patient confidentiality always

definitions: legally or morally require someone to do something as duty
do something as a favor or service to help someone
make someone grateful or indebted through kind actions
examples: The law obliges employers to provide safe working conditions always
Parents are obliged to ensure their children attend school regularly
Could you oblige me by holding this door open please?
The pianist obliged with an encore after enthusiastic applause
You would oblige me greatly by accepting this small gift
Their generous hospitality obliged us to reciprocate the invitation

definitions: destroy something completely leaving no trace or remnant behind
remove all traces of something by erasing or covering it completely
examples: The bombing obliterated entire city blocks during the war
The tsunami obliterated coastal villages within minutes of striking
Time had obliterated all traces of the ancient civilization completely
She obliterated his name from all her personal records yesterday

definitions: make something difficult to understand by making it unclear or ambiguous
block something from view by covering or concealing it physically
examples: Technical jargon often obscures the meaning of scientific papers
His vague answers obscured his true intentions from everyone present
Dark clouds obscured the mountain peaks all morning yesterday
The tall buildings obscure our view of the ocean completely

definitions: watch someone or something carefully and attentively for information
notice or perceive something through careful attention and awareness
follow or comply with rules, customs, or religious practices
make a comment or remark about something you have noticed
examples: Scientists observe animal behavior in their natural habitats carefully
The detective observed the suspect's movements for several days
I observed several mistakes in the report during my review
She observed that he seemed nervous during the interview yesterday
Many families observe traditional holidays with special meals and rituals
All students must observe the school's dress code policy strictly
The professor observed that attendance had declined significantly this semester
She observed wryly that the meeting accomplished nothing productive yesterday

definitions: block a road, path, or entrance preventing movement through it
deliberately hinder or prevent the progress of something or someone
examples: Fallen trees obstructed the mountain road after the storm yesterday
The protestors obstructed traffic during rush hour this morning
The senator obstructed the bill's passage through procedural delays repeatedly
Don't obstruct justice by withholding evidence from the investigation

definitions: get, acquire, or secure something through effort or request
be prevalent or exist as a general condition or situation
examples: She obtained permission to access the restricted archives yesterday
You can obtain a copy of the report from the office
These conditions no longer obtain in modern democratic societies today
The same rules obtain regardless of your social status here

definitions: cause something to happen or come about as a consequence
bring about or give rise to a particular situation or event
examples: His rude behavior occasioned many complaints from other customers yesterday
The announcement occasioned widespread celebration throughout the entire country
The accident occasioned a complete review of safety procedures immediately
Her absence occasioned considerable concern among her colleagues this morning
